Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Astronomy at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (2012-2016)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates site at the National Optical Astronomy Observatory's Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO). The program offers six undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in publishable-quality research projects with scientists working at the forefront of astronomy and astrophysics. Students are supported at the observatories' compound in La Serena, Chile for 10 weeks during the (austral) summer, and each student is guaranteed a minimum of two nights observing time. Mentors are selected from the scientific staffs of CTIO, the Southern Observatory for Astronomical Research (SOAR) and the Gemini South 8-m telescope.

The students are exposed to the international nature of modern astronomy, and become more globally engaged through living and working abroad and interacting with the local staff and other students. Exposure to the life and operations of a major international observatory and the diversity of activities conducted therein is an invaluable experience for all concerned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the 2012–2016 award period, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site program, hosted at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) in Chile, provided the opportunity for 30 undergraduate students (16 women and 14 men) to engage in publication-quality astronomy research projects, while working in the vibrant environment of an international astronomical observatory.  The fundamental goal of this program was to provide research opportunities to six (6) US undergraduates annually and to train them in the three main tasks of being a professional observational astronomer: observation, analysis of results, and subsequent reporting and publication. 

The CTIO REU site program is a vital part of NOAO’s ongoing commitment to train the nation’s future scientists, academics, and young professionals. In an effort to provide opportunities for students representing the full spectrum of the US population, we made special efforts in advertising to and recruiting women and students from minority-rich backgrounds, especially those attending minority-serving institutions. Of the 30 students accepted, there were 6 minority students. The broadest goals of the CTIO REU site program are (1) to encourage undergraduates of all demographics, including women and those of minority-rich backgrounds, to pursue careers in science, (2) to foster high levels of scientific literacy among the future Science, Engineering, and Technology (SET) workforce, (3) to promote cross-cultural interaction and knowledge-sharing between US and Chilean students, (4) to stimulate general awareness of the remarkable achievements of US astronomy, and (5) to inspire interest in the future progress and welfare of US science.

REU students were hired as full-time research assistants for 10 weeks and were mentored by a professional astronomer as they completed an astronomy research project.  The REU program was run concurrently with a similar program for Chilean students, called the Práctica en Investigación en Astronomía (PIA) program, and the cross-cultural interactions between REU and PIA students were an important component of both programs.  Each REU and PIA student spent at least two nights taking images of astronomical objects of interest using telescopes on the mountaintop of Cerro Tololo. Students were trained how to process and calibrate these data to answer relevant scientific questions.  All participants were encouraged to attend the American Astronomical Society (AAS) winter meeting following their program to present a poster.  In addition to research projects, the CTIO REU site program featured lectures on relevant topics designed by the science staff as well as field trips to learn about some of the other major observatory sites in Chile.
